grave.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: the place in the ground where a dead body is buried
grave.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: At the head of the grave there was a small wooden cross.
grave.translation[0].note_box[0].section: In the churchyard, a man was digging a grave.
The stone marked the grave of their young daughter.
She was buried in a grave next to her older sister.
They found the woman’s remains in a shallow grave in the woods.
Plague victims were buried in a mass grave.
Until 1855, poor people here were buried in unmarked graves.
Walter died in 1922 and was buried in the family grave in Finchley cemetery.
He wept by her open grave.
The president visited the grave sites of 12 youths killed in recent bombings.
grave.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: grave problems, situations, or worries are very great or bad
grave.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: Matthew’s life is in grave danger.
The report expressed grave concern over the technicians’ lack of training.
I have grave doubts about his ability.
The situation is becoming very grave.
grave.translation[1].definitions[0].note: In everyday English, people usually use serious  rather than grave, and seriously rather than gravely:
I have serious doubts about whether he’s up to the job.
grave.translation[1].definitions[1].defi: looking or sounding quiet and serious, especially because something important or worrying has happened
grave.translation[1].definitions[1].exam: Turnbull’s face was grave as he told them about the accident.
grave.translation[2].definitions[0].defi: a grave accent is a mark put above a letter in some languages such as French to show the pronunciation, for example è
